text:
CIRCULATORY SYSTEM

Open circulatory system: primarily found in invertebrates. Here, the blood flows freely through cavities and there are no vessels to conduct the blood.

Closed circulatory system: is found in vertebrates and a few invertebrates like earthworms. This system has the presence of vessels that conduct blood throughout the body.

Fibrinogen is a glycoprotein complex that circulates in the blood of vertebrates. During tissue and vascular injury, it is converted enzymatically by thrombin to fibrin and then to a fibrin-based blood clot. Fibrin clots function primarily to occlude blood vessels to stop bleeding.

Matured red blood cells (erythrocytes) lacks nucleus. As red blood cells contain no nucleus, protein biosynthesis is currently assumed to be absent in these cells. Because of the lack of nuclei and organelles, mature red blood cells do not contain DNA and cannot synthesize any RNA, and consequently cannot divide and have limited repair capabilities.

Red blood cells (Erythrocytes) are formed in the red bone marrow of bones. Stem cells in the red bone marrow called hemocytoblasts give rise to all of the formed elements in blood. If a hemocytoblast commits to becoming a cell called a proerythroblast, it will develop into a new red blood cell.

Plasma is the liquid component of blood, in which the red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets are suspended. It constitutes more than half of the blood's volume and consists mostly of water that contains dissolved salts (electrolytes) and proteins. The major protein in plasma is albumin.

Agglutination is the process that occurs if an antigen is mixed with its corresponding antibody called isoagglutinin. This term is commonly used in blood grouping.

When an Rh- woman conceives a child with an Rh+ man, their child can be Rh- or Rh+. If the baby's blood type matches the mother's (both are Rh-), Rh causes no complications. This may not be the case however, if the baby's blood type is Rh+.

Problems arise when the baby’s Rh+ blood gets into the mother’s Rh- bloodstream by traveling through the placenta. Red blood cells with the Rh factor are foreign to the mother. In an attempt to fight off this foreign invader, her immune system produces antibodies against the Rh+ blood cells. The process is called sensitization — the mother is now sensitized to the Rh factor.

People with blood group O are general donors. Recipients with blood type AB can receive a blood or kidney from blood types A, B, AB and O. This implies that recipients with AB blood are compatible with any other blood type. AB is the universal recipient. People with blood group A can only receive blood from a person with blood group A, also people with blood group B can only receive blood from a person with blood group B. 

The spleen is an organ found in virtually all vertebrates. Similar in structure to a large lymph node, it acts primarily as a blood filter. The spleen plays important roles in regards to red blood cells (erythrocytes) and the immune system.

The lymph system maintains the body's fluid balance and fights infections. The lymph is a colourless fluid containing white blood cells, which bathes the tissues and drains through the lymphatic system into the blood stream. The main role of lymphatic system is to return amino acids and excess interstitial or extracellular fluid (containing oxygen, glucose, amino acids, and other nutrients needed by tissue cells) to the blood stream. It also functions in the absorption of fats and fat-soluble vitamins (Vit A, D, E, K) from the digestive system and the subsequent transport of these substances to the venous system to return them for circulation. 

Amphibians have a three-chambered heart - two atria and one ventricle. The mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood is kept to a minimum due to the timing of the contractions between the atria. This is called an incomplete double circulatory system.

Just like mammals, Birds carry out double circulation and have their heart divided into four chambers. Two upper thin-walled auricles and two lower thick-walled ventricles.  

 

UNN PUTME Examples

1. ……. consists mainly of water in the blood?

A. lymph B. plasma C. serum D. platelets

(B. Plasma is the liquid component of blood, in which the red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets are suspended. It constitutes more than half of the blood's volume and consists mostly of water that contains dissolved salts (electrolytes) and proteins. The major protein in plasma is albumin, 2014/2015, no 4)

 

2. Protein in plasma ………

A. causes clotting of blood B. causes increase in osmotic potential C. gives the blood its red colour D. regulates the acid-base balance of the blood

(A. Blood plasma contains fibrinogen, a large molecular weight, soluble protein. Conversion of fibrinogen into insoluble fibrin, and then cross-linking the fibrin, produces a tangled meshwork of filaments that comprises the blood clot. Plasma itself can clot, because it possesses fibrinogen)

 

3. All birds have ____.

A. two-chambered heart B. three-chambered heart C. four-chambered heart D. one-chambered heart

(C. Just like mammals, Birds carry out double circulation and have their heart divided into four chambers. Two upper thin-walled auricles and two lower thick-walled ventricles.  2005/2006, no 4)

 

4. Three chambered heart is found in

A. Insects B. Amphibians C. Man D. No animal

(B. Amphibians have a three-chambered heart - two atria and one ventricle. The mixing of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood is kept to a minimum due to the timing of the contractions between the atria. This is called an incomplete double circulatory system, 2010/2011, no 7)

 

5. The capillaries act as filters between

A. the veins B. the arteries C. the venules D. the arteries and the veins

(D. Capillaries, the smallest and most numerous of the blood vessels, form the connection between the vessels that carry blood away from the heart (arteries) and the vessels that return blood to the heart (veins). The primary function of capillaries is the exchange of materials between the blood and tissue cells, 2006/2007, no 13)

 

6. Which of the following is the function of lymph? 

A. Carries hormones round the body B. transports nutrients and oxygen from blood capillaries C. distributes heat uniformly round the body D. conveys amino acids and glucose from the small intestine to the liver

(B. it transports nutrients and oxygen from blood capillaries. The lymph system maintains the body's fluid balance and fights infections, 2019/2020, no 14)

 

7. In the adult mammalian blood, the cell which lack nuclei are the

A. erythrocytes B. lymphocytes C. leucocytes D. phagocytes

(A. Matured red blood cells (erythrocytes) lacks nucleus. As red blood cells contain no nucleus, protein biosynthesis is currently assumed to be absent in these cells, 2009/2010, no 11)

 

8. Carbon monoxide poison tissues by _____

A. constricting the blood vessels B. killing the cells C. combining with haemoglobin D. rupturing the blood vessels

(C. Carbon monoxide poisoning occurs when carbon monoxide builds up in your bloodstream. When too much carbon monoxide is in the air, your body replaces the oxygen in your red blood cells with carbon monoxide. This can lead to serious tissue damage, or even death, 2015/2016 II, no 4)

 

9. The structures that prevent food particles from escaping through the fish gills are called gill_____

A. arches B. filaments C. rakers D. lamellae

(C. The gill rakers prevent solid substances such as food from being carried out through the branchial clefts and protect the delicate gill, 2015/2016, no 5)

 

10. Erythrocytes are produced in the

A. spleen B. liver C. pancreas D. bone marrow

(D. Red blood cells (Erythrocytes) are formed in the red bone marrow of bones. Stem cells in the red bone marrow called hemocytoblasts give rise to all of the formed elements in blood)

 

11. if a child can receive blood from all donors, he belongs to the blood group

A. O, B. A, C. B, D. AB 

(D. People with blood group O are general donors. Recipients with blood type AB can receive a blood or kidney from blood types A, B, AB and O, 2017/2018 II, no 8)

 

12. When a red blood cell is placed in water, the process of water movement is____

A. osmosis B. diffusion C. imbibition D. active transport

(A. Osmosis is the movement of a solvent across a semipermeable membrane toward a higher concentration of solute (lower concentration of solvent). In biological systems, the solvent is typically water, but osmosis can occur in other liquids, supercritical liquids, and even gases, 2014/2015, no 4)

 

13. Which of these factors in the blood is responsible for blood clotting?

A. fibrinogen B. heparin C. plasma D. red blood cells

(A. Fibrinogen is a glycoprotein complex that circulates in the blood of vertebrates. During tissue and vascular injury, it is converted enzymatically by thrombin to fibrin and then to a fibrin-based blood clot, 2014/2015, no 6)

 

14. Crenation occur in the red blood cell when

A. it is placed in isotonic solution B. it is placed in hypertonic solution C. osmosis is allowed to occur D. transpiration occurs

(B. When a red blood cell is placed in a hypertonic solution, such as a highly saline environment, there is a lower concentration of solute particles inside the cell than outside in the extracellular space. As water leaves the cell, it shrinks and develops the notched appearance characteristic of crenation, 2006/2007, no 12).

 

15. A circulatory system that does not allow mixing oxygenated blood in the mammalian heart is referred to as

A. open B. double C. single D. closed

(B. Open circulatory system: primarily found in invertebrates. Here, the blood flows freely through cavities and there are no vessels to conduct the blood, 2007/2008, no 9)

 

16. In blood transfusion, agglutination occurs when____

A. white blood cells from two people meet B. two different antibodies meet C. two different antigen meet D. contrasting antigens and antibodies meet

(D. Agglutination is the process that occurs if an antigen is mixed with its corresponding antibody called isoagglutinin. This term is commonly used in blood grouping)

 

17. Genetic counselling is important when marriage is planned between a

A. Rh+ woman and Rh- man B. Rh- woman and Rh+ man C. Rh- man and Rh- woman D. Rh+ woman and Rh+ man

(B. When an Rh- woman conceives a child with an Rh+ man, their child can be Rh- or Rh+. If the baby's blood type matches the mother's (both are Rh-), Rh causes no complications. This may not be the case however, if the baby's blood type is Rh+, 2007/2008, no 12)

 

JAMB Examples

1. During blood transfusion, agglutination may occur as a result of the reaction between

A. contrasting antigens and antibodies B. two different antigens C. two different antibodies D. similar antigens and antibodies

(A. contrasting antigens and antibodies)

 

2. The reason why the flow of blood through the capillaries is very slow is

A. because the walls of capillaries are very thin B. to avoid high — blood pressure C. to ensure that the individual does not get dizzy D. to allow adequate time for exchange of materials

(D. to allow adequate time for exchange of materials)

 

3. Which of the following features is not a characteristic of arteries? Arteries 

A. possess valves at internals throughout their length. B. have thick muscular and elastic walls C. carry blood away from the heart D. transport oxygenated blood with the exception of the pulmonary artery.

(A. possess valves at internals throughout their length)
